message: It is an honor and a privilege to be elected to serve the people of Florida’s 17th District for the next two years. I am humbled by this opportunity and am reminded of the sacred trust the people have placed in me every time I put my hand on the bible and take the oath of office.
Today I reintroduced the Preventing Crimes Against Veterans Act - to put a stop to financial predators defrauding veterans from their well-earned benefits.
#HereWeGo from the Capitol with my sons Sean and Seamus #Steelers #SteelerNation
First week in review of 2017 - have a great weekend!

Today, I am grateful to have witnessed my second transfer of presidential power since I was elected to the House of Representatives. I am praying Donald Trump is a successful president for our country because with his success comes our country’s success.

Judge Neil Gorsuch has proved himself to be a strong defender of the Constitution through his service on the U.S. Court of Appeals 10th Circuit. His defense of life demonstrates that he is a fitting candidate to replace Antonin Scalia. Also, he was confirmed unanimously by the Senate 10 years ago for the Circuit Court. As such, the Senate should confirm Judge Gorsuch without delay.

Florida's 17th district is one of the largest citrus producing districts in the nation. Thanks to my friends at Florida Citrus Mutual for all the work that you do to bring the voices of growers across the state of Florida to Washington, D.C. by advocating on their behalf.
Another busy week here in Washington, D.C. Here's an update as to what we did
Saw this of my good friend Marco and wanted to share. God bless this great country of ours.
Vice President Pence stopped by the House today - he made my son Sean a peanut butter and jelly sandwich while we were on our way to vote
Got a surprise visit from my two Army buddies today, Former Captain Danny Lee and Former Captain Pavlovcak, who both served in the First Cavalry with me at Fort Hood.
Here's an update as to what happened this week in Congress -

Today America lost one of its best with the passing of my dear friend and former colleague Robert Michel. Bob was the definition of a public servant and the longest-serving minority leader in history. Although I never served with him, he was a mentor to me when I first got elected and I will always be grateful for his guidance. Rest easy Bob, you will be missed.
Last week my brother Brian, an Iraq  war veteran, was in town with his family so I gave them a tour of the Capitol Dome. The kids loved it and the views can't be beat.

I had the distinct pleasure of presenting Ret. Cpl. Raymond French, from Babson Park, with medals he earned from his service in the Korean War. Raymond reached out to my office and we were able to obtain his medals, nearly 65 years after he was discharged. We cannot thank him enough for his distinguished service to our country.

Today I met with a cross section of community leaders at Venice City Hall and was greeted by over 400 individuals participating in a rally organized by local Indivisible groups. I look forward to working with those who participated in the meeting, along with those who rallied outside, to make sure the work I do in Congress best serves the people of Southwest Florida.   https://rooney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rooney-hosts-community-leaders-greets-rally-in-venice

As the new Co-Chairman of the House of Representative’s Joint Strike Fighter Caucus, I am committed to delivering the full combat requirement of the F-35 -- the very best, most advanced stealth strike fighter aircraft in the world -- to all of our frontline Air Force, Navy and Marine Corps combat fighter squadrons.

As a former professor of Constitutional and Criminal Law at West Point, one of my favorite things is to get up in front of a classroom and engage with students. Thanks Lemon Bay High school for having me the other day to teach AP Government and Politics, I had a great time and hope the students learned something.

In his speech tonight, the President outlined a bold Republican agenda that the American people voted for in November. I look forward to working with my party and the President to rebuild and reinvest in our crumbling infrastructure, fix our broken health care system, and make it easier for American companies to do business here. After eight long years of serving in Congress under President Obama, I am optimistic about this important opportunity for Republicans to prove to the American people that they come first and we can get the job done.

To all of my constituents in Florida's 17th District - I will be hosting a town hall this Monday March 6th at the Englewood Event Center. Check my website for all the information, I'm looking forward to seeing you there.    https://rooney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-tom-rooney-town-hall-advisory

It was a busy week here in Washington - for those of you who are asking, I will be having a town hall this Monday in Englewood, check my website (rooney.house.gov) for all the details and I hope to see you there.

Thank you to everyone who came to today's town hall meeting - it went very smoothly thanks to the cooperation of my constituents, the venue hosts, my staff, and importantly the Charlotte County Sheriff's office. Now I'm heading back to Washington, D.C. so I can #domyjob
http://www.speaker.gov/general/american-health-care-act-fact-sheet
http://www.politico.com/story/2017/03/house-trump-russia-investigation-hearing-235789
Today I sent a letter to my Florida colleague Bill Nelson urging him to to work to confirm Judge Neil Gorsuch without delay.
Monday March 6, 2017 - Congressman Tom Rooney hosts town hall in Englewood, Florida
For those of you who missed it this week - my full town hall video is now up on my facebook page, you tube channel and website. Have a great weekend!

Today I sent a letter to President Donald Trump proposing a common-sense solution to accelerate federal investments in our country’s aging infrastructure. I look forward to hearing from him.  https://rooney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rooney-to-trump-let-s-make-infrastructure-a-again
I had a great time at the Okeechobee Rodeo, thanks everyone for having me.
Tara and I had breakfast at Vice President Pence's residence with the Prime Minister of Ireland - Happy St. Patrick's Day to all!
It was wonderful seeing Justine and Paul Devlin in Washington, D.C. celebrating their 60th wedding anniversary, what an accomplishment.
Happy St. Patrick's Day from Washington, D.C.

Happening now - the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence open hearing on our investigation into Russian active measures during the 2016 election campaign. You can watch it live here: https://youtu.be/9xSoCUGmh6s
I questioned NSA Director Rogers during the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence hearing - you can see my full line of questioning on my website.

Today was Brain Injury Awareness Day on Capitol Hill. I met with former Steelers Super Bowl Champion Sean Morey and the wife of the late Justin Strzelczyk, Keana McMahon. Both Sean and Keana spoke to me about the importance of children playing flag football until the age of 14. They emphasized that research shows a developed brain is more equipped to deal with trauma, like concussions, after the age of 14. I thank them and everyone else who participated today for their advocacy efforts.
What I'm Watching:

I am extremely disappointed, though utterly unsurprised, that Senator Nelson would put political posturing above the needs of the American people. Ten years ago, not a single Democratic Senator opposed Neil Gorsuch’s confirmation for the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, including Senator Nelson. Nelson has not provided any substantive concerns or misgivings as to why he supported Gorsuch in the past but will not vote to confirm now. Nelson is hypocritically putting his own wants and needs above objectively considering a Judge who has shown nothing but full capability to serve on the Supreme Court.
Thanks to my friends from Florida's Cattlemen Association for stopping by my Washington, D.C. office today
Truth.

Today in my Deputy Whip Meeting - it was such an honor to get to listen to one of my policy heroes, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, to get her seasoned and well-reasoned perspective on the state of global affairs. She talked about the urgency of stopping North Korea’s nuclear program, countering Russian propaganda around the world and the importance of a broad national security budget that provides the military resources needed to defeat ISIS now and to keep these areas secure well into the future.
What I'm Reading:

I have never once wanted to just let Obamacare fail to prove a political point. But for some in our party, letting Obama’s health care plan fail is the strategy. That is not fair and it’s not right. That’s not solving problems, it’s childish. As elected officials, we are sent here to make tough choices and to represent the people – not to be obstructionists for the sake of it or because it makes us famous on Cable TV. Or worse yet, because it helps out our re-elections, and being called congressman is more important than actually serving as one. As I sit here today I honestly don’t know what the future holds for healthcare.
What I'm Reading:
The Democrats are forcing the Republicans to use the nuclear option on Judge Gorsuch. This is the first time in history that the U.S. Senate filibuster will be used for purely political purposes.
A great man. A great leader.

Today I met with Colonel Jason A. Kirk, Commander and District Engineer of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Jacksonville District. We discussed critical Army Corps projects in my district, like the Herbert Hoover Dike and Manasota Key, and how we can work together to get those projects funded and completed.

I am confident that our Committee will continue to conduct a thorough, bipartisan investigation into this matter. I look forward to working with Rep. Mike Conaway and Rep. Trey Gowdy to follow the facts where they lead us and report our findings to the American people as soon as possible. I will not be giving further comments until the investigation is concluded in order to protect the sanctity of the process.
Here's an update as to what happened this week in Congress
My thoughts and prayers go out to all those impacted by last weeks' tornado. Should there be anything my office can do, please do not hesitate to reach out.
A beautiful video of beautiful Punta Gorda
Rest in Peace Uncle Dan. Thanks for your mentorship and love.
Happy Easter from the Rooney's 2017

As the opioid epidemic continues to race across the country at devastating rates, Congressman Tom Rooney (R-FL) is pushing to get illicit drugs off the streets and bring funding home for Florida to help combat the issue. The Federal Law Enforcement Officers Association (FLEOA) endorsed Rooney’s legislation H.R. 1781, The Comprehensive Fentanyl Control Act of 2017, while the Department of Health and Human Services granted Florida millions of dollars to combat the opioid epidemic.

I am proud to represent one of the largest agriculture districts east of the Mississippi River and I am excited to get to work with Secretary Perdue about issues most important to Florida’s Agriculture industry. We have a lot to work on from funding citrus greening research initiatives to enhancing a Foot-and-Mouth Disease Vaccine Bank. I have every confidence that Secretary Perdue will be the best advocate in this administration for the farmers and ranchers I represent in Florida’s Heartland as Congress continues to move forward through the 2018 budget process and importantly with the reauthorization of the Farm Bill.

Most importantly, we passed what’s called a continuing resolution, commonly called a CR, to keep the government funded through the end of next week. While I am not a big supporter of CRs in general, I supported this one so the Appropriations Committee can hash out the final details of the 11 bills that will fund federal agencies like the Departments Defense, Agriculture and Homeland Security for the rest of this year.

“Ileana Ros-Lehtinen is a force in every sense of the word. She has had an extraordinary life in public service, starting out as a teacher and rising to become the first Hispanic woman in Congress and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee." - Speaker Paul Ryan
Great for Tara and me to see Senator Bob Dole at the White House tonight. One of the greatest of the Greatest Generation.

Today we remember what some called the "Day of days." 73 years ago, along with the British and Canadians, the United States stormed the beaches of Normandy. June 6th will always be fixed in our national memory as D-Day and represents the very best of the American spirit.

"The Financial CHOICE Act is a jobs bill, and one that will bring hope back to Main Street. It is easy to talk about the economy and regulations as a series of numbers. It is easy to talk in vague terms about ‘job creators’ and ‘small business owners.’ But what is far more important is identifying the problems they face and actually doing something to help them and make a difference in their lives."

The Financial CHOICE Act protects the community banks and credit unions from regulations that were never meant to apply to them. It will help small businesses and farmers gain access to capital – so they can expand, create jobs, and grow our economy. The CHOICE Act ends taxpayer funded bailouts, so if a big bank fails it will go through bankruptcy and it also puts in place the toughest penalties for financial fraud in history. I know businesses in Florida’s heartland have been suffering, I was proud to support a bill that will help the small businesses that make our Florida communities thrive. This bill will give Americans more choice, will create jobs, and significantly benefit our economy.
What I'm Reading:

Our men and women who selflessly put their lives on the line have a hard enough time receiving care as it is without the VA closing the clinics that are closest to their homes. In closing these facilities, the VA is directly marginalizing the veterans choosing to make a home in Florida’s heartland. We promised rural veterans across the country the benefits and care they deserve, and if the VA proceeds and shuts down these facilities, they’ll be sending a signal to the veterans that I represent that they don’t justify the minimal cost it takes to provide them with care.

Every year, I play first base for the Republicans in a charity baseball game versus the Democrats - it's a lot of fun for a good cause. This photo is of my family before the game two years ago. This morning I left practice early, at 7:05, so I could drive my kids to their last day of school. At 7:09 a gunman shot my friend and second baseman Steve Scalise, two Capitol Police officers and two staffers. Only moments before, Steve and I were working on double plays. Then I left early, which I never do, but did today because it was the last day of school. Then I heard that Steve was shot, at baseball practice, for charity. Please say a prayer for Steve and the others who were injured. Thanks to the Capitol Police detail that was there, without whom the situation could have been much worse. I hope we still play the game tomorrow. Finally, thanks for all the emails and texts – it means a lot. - Tom
Congratulations to Kutter Crawford, from Okeechobee, for being drafted to the Boston Red Sox.

Tonight we will play the Congressional baseball game – like we have every year since 1909. I will proudly put on my uniform, to partake in America’s favorite pastime with my friends and colleagues, with my family watching in the stands. This game truly embodies what it means to be an American; it reminds us of our common ideals, common goals, and common humanity. From the outside, Washington always appears to be full of toxic partisanship. But I am here to tell you that from inside the beltway, I am honored to play this game and work in this place with men and women- from both sides of the aisle- who fiercely love their nation and do what they believe is right for this country every day. Additionally, we raise a lot of money for Boys & Girls Club of Greater Washington, Washington Literacy Center, the Washington Nationals Dream Foundation and, in support of yesterday's shooting, the Capitol Police Memorial Fund.
Let's play ball

Thursday's Congressional Baseball Game for Charity raised over $1.5 million with 24,959 in ticket sales. The game took on a more profound meaning after Wednesday’s shooting. I am proud to have been a part of such a wonderful event.

Yesterday, we questioned former DHS Secretary Jeh Johnson as part of our investigation to uncover the extent of Russian cyber activity directed against our state and local elections systems before the 2016 election. The Constitution entrusts our state and local elections officials with the sole authority to ensure our elections systems are secure, free and fair. I asked Secretary Johnson to explain his designation of elections systems as “critical infrastructure” and to assure me that the federal government would not interfere with state control over elections systems. He said that if sophisticated threats keep coming from nations like Russia, that his designation helps elections officials move up in the line to receive assistance from the government to help combat these threats – BUT ONLY if they request it. Thanks to all of Florida’s Elections Supervisors who keep our democracy thriving with each election.
Here's an update as to what happened this week in Congress.

Today is National PTSD Awareness Day. As a co-chair of the Military-Veterans Caucus and the Military Mental Health Caucus, as well as being an Army veteran, I often get to see and hear about the advances we’re making in treating PTSD. Today, I attended the Veterans Suicide Prevention Briefing shortly before Secretary Shulkin announced that the VA would be providing emergency mental health coverage to former service members with other than honorable administrative discharges. The mental health and wellness of our former services members is critically important to me, and I look forward to working with my colleagues in Congress as well as Secretary Shulkin to do all we can to help those in need.
The opioid epidemic has been spreading across the country, destroying families, at a terrifying rate. This bill is a necessary step in getting dangerous synthetic fentanyls out of our communities.

In 2015, a young woman named Kate Steinle was murdered by an illegal immigrant while she was on an evening walk with her father in San Francisco. The killer had been convicted of multiple felonies and deported back to Mexico five times before he was able to return to the U.S. to carry out this heinous act of violence. San Francisco’s sanctuary policies failed Kate, the Steinle family and their entire community. Had our immigration laws been properly enforced, Kate’s tragic death could have been prevented.

Before this week's week in review, I want to congratulate my alma-mater, the University of Florida, for winning the men’s college World Series. UF is now the 4th school in history to win a title in football, baseball and men’s basketball. Congratulations to all the guys on this team and thanks for making all UF alumni, like me, proud.

This week, my 2017 Congressional Art Competition winner Shakira Zertuche, from Mulberry High School, came to Washington, D.C. Shakira got to see where her artwork, titled "Man Made," will hang for the next year for all of the Capitol's visitors to get to see.

Ambassador Anne Anderson is retiring as Ambassador of Ireland to the United States. Anne has truly made this Ambassadorship her own and has made the American Irish relationship stronger. She has been an incredible advocate for the Irish people and as a proud Irishman, I am very sad to see her go. I wish her all the best in her retirement and her return home to Ireland – Anne, God Bless.

I am very proud to have been named to the United States Military Academy Board of Visitors and was grateful to meet with USMA Superintendent LTG Robert Caslen. As a former professor of Constitutional and Criminal Law at West Point, I know firsthand that our cadets serving at West Point are a critical part of our future. I look forward to doing all that I can to ensure their success.
Happy Independence Day to you and yours - May God Bless America
What I'm Reading:

So honored to participate in my first Board of Visitors meeting at the United States Military Academy, accompanied by my son who was born at West Point almost 14 years ago when my wife and I were stationed here as Captains in the Army.

Congressman Tom Rooney obtained millions of federal dollars in critical funding for Florida in the Appropriations Committee’s Agriculture and Energy & Water bills, which both passed today in the Appropriations Committee.

Today the House passed the 2018 National Defense Authorization Act. I included an amendment to this bill which will ensure that service members with TBI and PTSD are given a fair consideration during military separations. These men and women put their lives on the line to defend our country and it is our responsibility to care for them and take all factors into consideration in military separations
Took my family to the West Wing today.
National "I love horses" day. My son with Ginger Nation.

Great morning in Punta Gorda, getting to meet with the Young Farmers and Ranchers Farm Bureau leadership program. It's always encouraging to talk to the next generation of agriculture leaders and see what the future holds.

One of my favorite responsibilities as a member of Congress is making Congressional nominations for young people to attend the service academies. My office is accepting applications and I invite all those interested to apply or contact my office with any questions that you might have.
This week, I did an interview with the New York Times to talk about what it's actually like to be a Member of Congress - I encourage you to listen and I would love to hear what you think.
Today I spoke on the House floor to congratulate the Young Guns of Quail Creek for winning the 2017 Scholastic Clay Target Program National Championship. Thanks for making Florida-17 proud!

"The citrus industry in Florida has been fighting citrus greening for years and without immediate action Florida orange juice will be a thing of the past. This legislation is critical to not only fund research but to help growers replace trees in order to keep producing oranges."

Our men and women who selflessly put their lives on the line have a hard enough time receiving care as it is without the VA closing the clinics that are closest to their homes. By keeping these clinics open the VA is showing their commitment to our veterans and ensuring they receive the best and most convenient care.

It was a busy week this week in Congress – what with the Senate healthcare debates, the Appropriations bills that passed in the House, the citrus bill I introduced and everything in between. Here you can hear more about what we did:

As Tropical Storm Emily approaches Southwest Florida please stay alert and follow all FEMA and National Hurricane Center's guidance. Should you need any additional assistance please feel free to contact my office.
What I'm Reading:
The U.S. Senate on Wednesday passed legislation that is considered to be the largest expansion of veterans education benefits in a decade.
We had a great group of interns in our Washington, D.C. office this summer - thanks for all your hard work!

It is my honor to welcome the U.S. Secretary of Agriculture, Sonny Perdue, to Florida’s 17th District. We are starting the day by touring a variety of Alico, Inc’s groves in Punta Gorda to get an up-close look at the effects of citrus greening disease on Florida’s citrus industry and see some of the strategies and therapies that are working to help fight it. We are committed to beating this disease and returning the industry to prosperity. I am grateful that the Secretary is taking the time to understand this disease from the perspective of those on the front lines.

Secretary Perdue and I participated in a productive and timely roundtable discussion with local growers, researchers and a variety of other citrus industry stakeholders who explained the challenges of combating greening and the status of ongoing research to find a cure. FL Citrus Mutual President Mike Sparks moderated the event, which provided the Secretary the opportunity to hear from the people at the forefront of the fight and I am confident that he will work with Congress and our state to develop the most effective strategy to combat citrus greening moving forward.

Last night, Secretary Perdue and I capped off his visit to the 17th District at the Gulf Citrus Growers Citrus and Agriculture Industry Celebration. Secretary Perdue addressed a number of industry stakeholders and expressed his support to help us save our citrus. It is great to know that Florida’s Citrus Industry now has a powerful ally in the administration.

This morning I had the privilege of accompanying USDA Secretary Perdue, Vice Chairman of the Florida Conservation Group Jim Strickland, USDA's Florida Conservationist Russell Morgan, and the Conservation Program Manager at the National Wildlife Refuge Association Julie Morris, on a helicopter tour of environmental projects in Florida’s heartland. We viewed land that local ranchers have dedicated for the preservation of Florida’s natural waterways and agricultural lands through state and federally-funded conservation easements. I am glad the Secretary was able to see the unique, functioning dynamic among farmers, ranchers and environmental groups in Florida who are working together to keep Florida beautiful.

This week, I had the distinct honor of presenting the Army Good Conduct Medal, American Campaign Medal, Europe-Africa-Middle East-Medal with two bronze battle stars for service in the Ardennes and Rhineland Campaigns, and the World War II Victory Medal to the family of the late Edwin W. Janz. Sadly, Mr. Janz, one of the last remaining survivors of the Battle of the Bulge, and one of the first Americans to arrive in Berlin the day Aldolph Hitler died and Nazi Germany fell, passed away on Monday. However, his legacy will not soon be forgotten. I am humbled and extremely grateful to live in a nation that is protected by brave service members like Edwin Janz. He was a true American hero and he will be missed.

Sending our thoughts and prayers to the US sailors and their families who were lost in the USS John McCain collision off the coast of Singapore.

What I'm Reading: Last night in Arlington, VA, President Trump announced our new U.S. strategy in Afghanistan and South Asia. While we are quick to jump on the President’s mistakes, we should be equally ready to give him credit for making a difficult decision. He didn’t embrace this decision easily, and it wasn’t until he became President that he could fully understand the consequences of a lawless Afghanistan. While all of us wish the longest war in U.S. history was over and the Taliban, ISIS and Al Qaeda were no more, this is simply not the reality. The truth is that those groups hate our country and the ideals that we stand for. They want America and our way of life to fall. The President is keeping his promises to not make arbitrary deadlines or project numbers, while accepting that his most important duty as Commander-in-Chief is to keep us safe. As long as there is a threat in Afghanistan, it is his job to stop it. Last night the President told our men and women in uniform that he was going to do just that. I have the utmost faith that our brave service members will dutifully answer his call.

Today I visited with first responders, law enforcement and emergency management officials from across Florida’s 17th District who worked tirelessly to prepare and protect our communities from Hurricane Irma. As we all begin to recover and rebuild from the destruction, I want you to know that my office is here to help. President Trump has issued a Major Disaster Declaration for all of Florida’s 67 counties, which makes federal funding available for cleanup and recovery efforts. To find out about local disaster recovery resources and to determine if you are eligible for disaster assistance, visit https://www.disasterassistance.gov/. I also urge you to contact my office at 202-225-5792 if you have any questions or if you need non-emergency assistance. The resiliency of Floridians is unmatched and I know that we will come together and make our communities even stronger than they were before.

FEMA Approves All Counties in District 17 for Individual Assistance, which includes: Charlotte, Desoto, Glades, Hardee, Highlands, Lee, Okeechobee, Sarasota and Polk Counties  https://rooney.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/fema-approves-all-counties-in-district-17-for-individual-assistance
If you live in Highlands County, please see the below information on where meals will be distributed today:

Today I was invited to join President Trump, Vice President Pence, Secretary Rick Perry, and others on a trip to Lee County, Florida to survey the damage caused by Hurricane Irma. We spoke about a number of things including fuel shortages and quickly restoring power to those who have been left in the dark, especially in rural areas. I also continue to be impressed by the resolve of the first responders and volunteers that I spoke with throughout the day. The administration is committed to doing everything that it can to aid in and expedite recovery efforts in our home state and I am confident that we will rebuild our communities. Please know that I am here to help in any way that I can. Should you need assistance, please do not hesitate to call my office at 202-225-5792.

My office has just been informed that free hot meals will be available from 4:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. at:  670 Milwaukee Blvd, Lehigh Acres, FL 33974

DeSoto County Emergency Management:  The Salvation Army has set up a mobile cantina to serve hot meals starting at 6 PM tonight. It is located at the old Winn Dixie building at 1330 E OAK ST (hwy 70) in Arcadia. This is open to anyone to come get a hot meal for dinner.

I just wanted to take a moment to provide you with an update on the latest information we're receiving on the power situation in Highlands County, the second hardest-hit county in Florida. I’ve heard from many of you whose power has been out for almost a week now (mine is as well), and the impact it's had on you and your families, which is made a lot worse in the Florida heat. I want to assure you that my staff and I have been in constant contact with Duke Energy and multiple agencies at the federal, state, and local levels to ensure that much-needed supplies make it to your County. Just today, Duke Energy reported that 20,945 customers have had their power restored in Highlands. Though it doesn’t make the situation any better, I think it’s important for folks to understand the extent of the damage that the electrical grid in the area sustained—parts of the grid in Highlands County are essentially being rebuilt from scratch. One issue that companies are facing is a lack of resources due to high demand. Duke alone had 3,000 poles and 1,000 miles of wire go down, which they need to either repair, stand back up or replace. Sometimes even if they have crews in place, they’re still waiting for supplies to arrive. Duke has told us that much-needed resources are headed to Highlands County and that they feel that, even though the grid is badly-damaged in some places, they’ve reached a turning point. Hopefully many more residents in Highlands will begin to see their power restored throughout the next week. I know you are very frustrated, and I am too - but I will keep making sure the needs of Florida's heartland are not forgotten about. As always, should you need any assistance or have any questions, please do not hesitate to call my office at 202-225-5792.

Update from Florida Power and Light: Thousands of restoration personnel continue working around the clock to restore the remaining customers of Florida Power & Light Company (FPL) without power due to Hurricane Irma. With most major lines and critical infrastructure now restored, more and more crews are transitioning to tackle smaller groups of outages in thousands of neighborhoods across the state.   • FPL customers in Clay and Highlands counties impacted by Irma are more than two-thirds restored and should be 90 percent restored by Sunday night with full completion Monday • In Sarasota and Manatee counties, restoration is more than 78 percent complete and are projected to be completed several days earlier than originally estimated. They are now both on track to reach 90 percent restoration Monday and be essentially complete on Wednesday.  • Restoration is also progressing more quickly than initially estimated in Charlotte, DeSoto and Hendry counties, where more than 80 percent of FPL customers have been restored. Restoration is projected to reach 90 percent Tuesday and wrap up on Wednesday.  • Lee and Glades counties are more than 60 percent restored and are projected to be completed about a day earlier than initially estimated, with 90 percent restored by Wednesday night and the remaining customers restored by Thursday night.   I will continue to coordinate with all of the energy providers in the 17th District and keep you all update as I receive new information.

Today I took an aerial tour of Highlands, Desoto, Hardee, and Glades Counties with U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Sonny Perdue, Agriculture Commissioner of Florida Adam Putnam, and Senator Marco Rubio to assess the damage caused by Hurricane Irma to Florida's agriculture industry. We also attended a briefing hosted by a number of industry stakeholders to hear how they have each been impacted by the devastation of Hurricane Irma, and how we, as government officials, can help as they begin the recovery process.

*UPDATE: FL-17 BLUE ROOF LOCATIONS*   Operation Blue Roof is a program that provides a temporary covering of blue plastic sheeting to help reduce further damage to property until permanent repairs can be made. This program is available at no cost to eligible primary homeowners with less than 50 percent structural damage in Charlotte, DeSoto, Glades, Hardee, Highlands, Lee, Polk, and Sarasota counties. Other counties may be added at a later date.  To get assistance, you are required to sign a “Right of Entry” (ROE) form to allow Corps staff and contractors to access your private property and assess roof damage. You must sign up in person once a Blue Roof location has been established in your area. At this time, Operation Blue Roof has set up in the following locations in FL-17, which are open from 8 a.m. until 6 p.m.:  -Lee: Lowes Home Improvement Center, 8040 Dani Drive, Fort Myers, FL 33966  -Hardee: Hardee County Library, 315 N. 6th Ave. Wauchula, FL 33873  -Highlands: County Civic Center, 4509 George Blvd. Sebring, FL 33875 (staff will be at the east end of the parking lot)   -Polk: Near Airport, 5253 Airport Blvd. Bartow, FL  -Sarasota: Bee Ridge Park, 4430 South Lockwood Ridge Rd. Sarasota, FL  Before you go, determine if you qualify for the program:   1.  The home must be the primary residence* of the person or household requesting the emergency roof covering; AND  2. The residence has more than 50 percent of the roof framing undamaged. The framing must support the plastic sheeting as a temporary repair, and be able to provide safe shelter once contractors install the tarp; AND  3. The resident certifies that he or she is the owner of the residence requested to be covered OR is a renter that has obtained legal permission to continue occupying the residence until more permanent repairs are made; AND  4. The resident certifies that they will shelter in the residence that they have requested to be covered; AND  5. The roof must be standard roof shingles, or a similar material that will allow contractors to nail the tarp in place. Contractors will consider repairs to metal roofs and mobile homes on a case-by-case basis and will install the cover if possible.  Contractors cannot cover roofs made of materials such as slate, asbestos or clay tile, or other material which would be exceptionally difficult to repair, or would likely be damaged during tarp installation.

Today, the US Department of Agriculture approved Florida's request to operate a Disaster Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (D-SNAP) in the 48 counties already-declared as major disaster assistance areas. The FL Department of Children and Families (which is the state agency that will administer the program) estimates that around 2.4 million new households may apply for D-SNAP and over 1 million existing SNAP households may be eligible for additional assistance. Eligible households will receive 2 months of benefits. Each county's application dates will vary to ensure adequate staffing capacity at each application site. The Department of Children and Families has provided a tentative schedule of operations and is still finalizing the application locations for each county. Listed below are the tentative dates for residents in FL-17 to apply:  Okeechobee: 10/6 through 10/10 Polk: 10/14 - 10/18 Highlands and Hardee: 10/14 - 10/16 Sarasota: 10/15 - 10/19 Lee: 10/25 - 10/30 Charlotte and Glades: 10/28 - 10/30 Desoto: 10/13 - 10/14  To stay updated on application dates and locations, to learn if you're eligible to pre-register for D-SNAP online and for additional details about the program, please visit the Food for Florida website: https://www.dcf.state.fl.us/programs/access/fff/

You only have two weeks to apply for federal disaster assistance. Assistance may cover temporary housing, essential home repairs and serious disaster-related needs not covered by insurance.   Disaster assistance is available to eligible individuals and households in the 48 disaster-designated counties with storm-related damages. The deadline to apply for assistance is Thursday, Nov. 9.  The quickest way to apply for federal assistance is online at www.disasterassistance.gov. Survivors may also apply by phone at 800-621-3362 (Voice, 711 or VRS) or 800-462-7585 (TTY). Due to high demand, lines may be busy during the day. Try calling in the morning or evening when call volume may be lower. The FEMA Helpline numbers are open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. (ET), seven days a week until further notice.

The deadline to apply for federal disaster assistance has been EXTENDED. Assistance may cover temporary housing, essential home repairs and serious disaster-related needs not covered by insurance.   Disaster assistance is available to eligible individuals and households in the 48 disaster-designated counties with storm-related damages. The deadline to apply for assistance has now been extended to Friday, November 24th.   The quickest way to apply for federal assistance is online at www.disasterassistance.gov. Survivors may also apply by phone at 800-621-3362 (Voice, 711 or VRS) or 800-462-7585 (TTY). Due to high demand, lines may be busy during the day. Try calling in the morning or evening when call volume may be lower. The FEMA Helpline numbers are open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. (ET), seven days a week until further notice.

NOTICE: My mobile office hours in Sebring today have been cancelled. I apologize for any inconvenience.  However, staff members will be available to assist you with any issues you are having with a federal agency. They will be available until 12:00 p.m.

For years, a rising number of Americans said the American Dream was out of reach. Since the election of President Trump, more people are more hopeful. But we can do more for individuals and families by making sure they keep more of what they earn.

As most of you my age and older know, Ronald Reagan was the last president to sign into law major tax reforms. This bill reduces the number of individual tax brackets. Unless you and your spouse make over $1 million a year, the rate you pay in taxes before factoring in deductions will go down.
